Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: An Integrated Simulation and Process Control Platform for Distributed Manufacturing Process Chains

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Rapid and customized part realization in all industrial sectors imposes stringent demands on part attributes, e.g., mechanical properties, microstructure, surface finish, geometry, etc. However, part attributes can very rarely be directly measured and/or controlled in the production process. Instead, measurements are taken of accessible and measurable primary process responses that are known to influence the part's attributes. These primary process responses are then controlled through the manipulation of a set of controllable process parameters. This widely used strategy is based on the assumption that the proper control of the primary process responses will implicitly yield the desired part attributes. The current work aims to replace this implicit assumption by a model-based explicit evaluation of the part's attributes that uses newly established process models, available measurements of process responses and historical data from a data base that is continuously updated. In effect, this approach implies a direct instead of an implicit control of the part's desired attributes and, as such, also moves a step closer to rapid part certification.

The research will establish the scientific and technological foundation for a manufacturing platform in a distributed network that seamlessly and efficiently integrates physical processes and numerical simulations in a fast predictive framework. The platform is envisioned as a multi-loop simulation and control environment consisting of four control loops running at different time scales. Two of the control loops, similar in structure to conventional controllers, act at the hardware-level and are devoted to the physical control of the relevant process variables while the other two are devoted to the software-level model-based evaluation of the desired part attributes. The latter two instruct the hardware-level controllers on required changes in their behavior that are necessary to reach the desired part attributes. To enable the integration, a voxel-based geometric model powered by an underlying data structure capable of dynamically generating analysis information, storing experimental information, and encoding the final part attributes obtained from the simulation and measured results will be established. This geometrical representation is well-suited to the use of general purpose graphics processing units (GPGPU) for fast computation of the process models that determine the physical process responses and attributes in arbitrary regions of a part. The researched framework will be validated using the state-of-the art open-architecture Directed Energy Deposition machine at Northwestern equipped with networked real-time sensing and control.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Rapid and customized part realization in all industrial sectors coupled with stringent requirements on part feature size, form and tolerances, material properties, part microstructure, and surface properties to mention a few have outpaced our ability to provide adequate manufacturing engineering solutions. Compounding this challenge is the need to work with multi-material structures, multi-scale geometric features, prescribed surface integrity, defined mechanical and physical properties of the parts produced, complex processing chains, and short time frames. Yet even a cursory reflection on the landscape of manufacturing process technologies in use reveals that it is very seldom that one of the above-mentioned part ?attributes? is directly measured and/or controlled. The reason is that it is generally impossible, at the current state of technology, to measure in real-time or near real-time most of a part?s attributes of interest. Instead, measurements are taken of certain accessible and relatively easily measurable ?process responses? that are indirectly/implicitly related to the desired part attributes. This indirect/implicit control of the desired part attributes hinders the implementation of the full potential of the manufacturing processes in terms of both outcome and efficiency.

In response to the above-stated challenges, the aim of the research was to establish the scientific and technological foundation for a futuristic manufacturing platform in a distributed network that seamlessly and efficiently integrates physical processes, numerical process simulations, and real-time process control/monitoring in a fast predictive framework. The platform is powered by and rooted in the evolving cyber-physical infrastructure to allow users to quickly determine the process parameters needed to yield the desired part attributes in each process or process chain. At the forefront of this innovation were processes in which geometrically and structurally complex parts defined by Computer Aided Design (CAD) digital models can be produced. Despite the flexibility of such processes, functional part properties and performance are difficult to predict. To overcome this hurdle, the newly developed processing platform integrates part geometry, process parameters, numerical process simulation outcomes based on physical process models, and predicts part behavior via a common data structure for process control and certification purposes.

The work was accomplished through three intricately interwoven contributions. First, the inception of a fundamentally new volumetric data representation method capable of efficiently storing geometric description, manufacturing process parameters, simulation data, metrology information and part attributes information. This was coupled with very efficient modeling techniques and infused in a framework with native support for massively parallel processing optimized for performance on Graphical Processing Units (GPUs). Second, a methodology for efficiently predicting part attributes using new reduced-order models developed from fine-scale multi-physics process simulations and experiments. Third, a multi-loop control structure with the requisite real-time sensing, networking and control algorithms that demonstrates the ability of the platform to monitor and control part attributes. As a principal vehicle to demonstrate the feasibility and utility of the developed platform the Directed Energy Deposition Process was used. In this endeavor, new physical models for microstructure evolution and melt pool behavior were also formulated.

The project has created an innovative framework and platform for predicting and controlling the necessary process parameters needed to produce a part with specified attributes. This allows users to input a CAD model and other requirements over a distributed platform and obtain a set of values for the process parameters and ultimately real-time control capabilities that yield the required performance of the manufactured part. The efficient reduced-order modeling techniques presented lay the foundation for future work in real-time process and process parameter optimization for a wide range of manufacturing applications. The abstract nature of the framework and supporting data structure make it easy to extend the formulation to other processes that utilize digital geometric models (e.g., machining, laser ablation, joining, etc.). The physically distributed nature of the system supports on-the-spot manufacturing in distributed locations, reduces the barriers for small and medium-size manufacturers in entering the competitive manufacturing business, and improves sustainability by optimizing attributes/properties virtually, eliminating material and power waste with reduced turnaround time. The architecture and flexibility of the system also serves as an educational platform for students with diverse backgrounds to experiment with part design in various processes, while its affordability facilitates the introduction of the framework to universities, and community colleges.
